content.description: <math alttext="K 2 S O 3 aqueous, plus 2 H N O 3 aqueous, reacts to produce, 2 K N O 3 aqueous, plus S O 2 gas, plus H 2 O liquid" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>→</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>KNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mtext>O</mtext><mo>(</mo><mi>l</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
content.question: According to the balanced chemical equation above, when <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 S O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is mixed with <math alttext="100.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>100.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> at <math alttext="30 degrees Celsius" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>30</mn><mi>°</mi><mtext>C</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="1 atmosphere" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>1 atm</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>, the volume of <math alttext="S O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> gas produced is <math alttext="0.24 liter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.</mn><mtext>24 L</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>. If it is assumed that the reaction goes to completion, which of the following changes would double the volume of <math alttext="S O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> produced at the same temperature and pressure, and why? (For each change, assume that the other solutions and volumes remain the same.)

choices.label: Using <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 S O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, because it then becomes the reactant in excess

Using <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of the <math alttext="0.200 molar H N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, because the volume of <math alttext="S O 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> produced is inversely proportional to the number of moles at constant temperature and pressure

Using <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 S O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, because this provides double the number of moles with the correct stoichiometric ratio

Using <math alttext="400.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>400.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 S O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, because this provides the same number of moles of each reactant

content.answer: Using <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.100 molar K 2 S O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.100</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>K</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><msub><mrow><mtext>SO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="200.0 milliliters" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>200.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>mL</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> of <math alttext="0.200 molar H N O 3 aqueous" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>0.200</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mi>M</mi><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>HNO</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>a</mi><mi>q</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, because this provides double the number of moles with the correct stoichiometric ratio

skill.text: 5.C: Explain the relationship between variables within an equation when one variable changes.
